title: Man who lay dead in a morgue for a WEEK as his family searched and were told he was still alive
text:
A waitress at the cafe where a man collapsed and was left dead in a morgue has revealed the sequence of events that sparked a week-long search for him as his family believed he was still alive.

Relatives of Jeffrey Conway spent more than a week searching for him after they were told he was discharged from Barwon Health Hospital in Geelong, Victoria.

Mr Conway, 64, was at Two Sugars cafe on September 20 when he collapsed and rushed to hospital, suffering from a heart attack.

The man who lay dead in a morgue for a week as his family searched for him after they were told he was alive has been revealed as Jeffrey Conway (left)

Relatives of Mr Conway spent more than a week searching for him after they were told he was discharged from Barwon Health Hospital in Geelong, Victoria

Waitress at the establishment, Tiettu Popping, told Nine News they were told Mr Conway was unconscious and doctors said he was not waking up.

Just two days later, Ms Popping went to the hospital to check on Mr Conway but was told the 64-year-old had been discharged.

On September 26, Mr Conway's sister called the cafe, stressing as she did not know her brother had been in hospital at all.

'I double checked and made sure this was the right man,' Ms Popping said.

The following day, the hospital also told the 64-year-old's sister that he had been discharged, so she filed a missing persons report.

It was then revealed that Mr Conway had died seven days before the missing persons report was submitted.

The investigation ended when police located his body in the morgue and are now looking into why the death notification was not followed up with the family.

Chief Commissioner Graham Ashton told Melbourne radio 3AW on Thursday that the case is now being followed up to give the family as much information as possible.

Mr Conway, 64, was at Two Sugars cafe on September 20 when he collapsed and rushed to hospital, suffering from a heart attack

'This is clearly a case where there's a mishap, in that the family haven't been notified when they should've been notified, and we have to make sure we look at how we get that right,' Mr Ashton said.

Barwon Health and Victoria Police are now liaising over the blunder, after they claimed police were contacted on the day Mr Conway died.

'Barwon Health has unreservedly apologises for the distress caused by the delay and the manner in which the family was notified of their relative's death,' the hospital said in a statement.

While hospital staff attempted multiple times to contact Mr Conway's next of kin, they had no luck and notified police.

Waitress at the establishment, Tiettu Popping (pictured), said they were told Mr Conway was unconscious and doctors said he was not waking up

Mr Conway was at Two Sugars (pictured) when he collapsed and suffered a heart attack

'We are awaiting advice regarding the internal communication between the police involved in the initial notification to police at the time of the patient's death and the police involved in the coroner's case,' the statement said.

If someone dies in hospital, the hospital usually notifies next of kin.

But in this case there 'might have been' an issue regarding the formal notification of the next of kin.

'The family have gone through a week of not knowing and having to deal with that, and then, in turn, having the ongoing grief they've got to go through compounded by it, so it's a sad case indeed,' Mr Ashton said.
